ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to go to peer tutoring hours, and do practice problems over and over
I learned about Calc II topics, such as integration, sequences and series, volume, and parametric equations.
I reinforced my knowledge of calculus and gained skills related to problem solving.
I think I became better at problem solving and evaluating different strategies I could use to solve a problem.
I learned how to better manage my time and what topics I should focus on through the support of my instructor.
Having taken Calculus BC in high school, this course refreshed my knowledge of the material while also going more in-depth than I have before in previous classes.

As I took this class my first semester, I learned how to facilitate a challenging class. As I received a high score on my first exam, I didnt put as much effort into the second one and I suffered the consequences. I learned that there are resources for help.

I developed my mathematical skills, particularly in the area of integration, and I gained insight into the application of these skills in real life scenarios (such as calculating the volume of a rotational solid and approximating functions using power series).

I learned analysis and evaluation over
Calculus topics
time management, study techniques, calculus, math, critical thinking
Lots of insight, feel like I understand the topic to a much deeper extent.
Learning to be organized in solving questions in problem sets.

As this was an introductory prerequisite, not much knowledge, skills, and insights developed from this course. Learned advanced integration techniques, taylor series, series tests, volume approximations, etc.
I learned how to understand higher-level calculus.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The weakness is letting kids that took calc BC take the class and teaching knowing that they have.

They definitely need more peer tutors at office hours. There were times when office hours would get really crowded and there were only 1 or 2 peer tutors available, which was really inefficient. The grading of exams also did not provide good feedback if you missed a question. There is also an extreme inconsistency of teaching quality across the various sections, so if you get an instructor that doesn't teach well, you're pretty unlucky and will have to do a lot of learning on your own, whereas if you get an instructor that's really great (like Rachel, the course head), then you will be much more prepared for exams. Another weakness is a lot of the busy work assignments. In addition to the PSETS, there is some busy work (e.g. explorations, learning strategies, etc.). Although they usually only take an extra 10-20 minutes, they are pretty unnecessary, but they are good buffer points. One of the strengths are the review sessions that are offered in preparation for the exams.
There were times when this class felt long and it moved too slowly. I would have like it to move slightly faster and to slow down when students had questions.
I think there could be more individual help because it felt pretty generalized but it was helpful to have scheduled reviews with different teachers before exams.

A major weakness of this course lies in the fact that each section is taught by a different instructor. This means that there is a wide range of teaching styles and consequently some students are at an advantage if they have a professor whose teaching aligns with their style of learning. 

A strength of this course is the peer tutoring as it is available practically every day of the week, meaning help is always accessible and available.

The step by step walkthrough of the topics was very helpful and allowed me to gain insight on the true nature of what we were studying. Perhaps more in class review of example problems could be helpful.

I thoroughly enjoyed the way the classes themselves were organized, especially around exams - there were lots of resources provided to ensure students were prepared for them. However, I think the classes could be more consistent. For example, I thought that Rachel's worksheets were very useful when learning the material, but I know that not all the sections utilized them.
The problems sets could be weighted more. It feels like they dont matter to your grade and yet they take multiple hours a week.

This course provides each student with plenty of assistance throughout the semester. I appreciated the nightly peer tutor sessions, the pre-exam review sessions, and the availability of professors during office hours. One way in which the course could be improved is if additional practice problems with an answer key were provided for each lesson so that students may receive additional practice throughout the semester or an answer key to the problem sets once the deadline for the problem sets have passed (at the moment, the only practice we can do with an answer key is the practice provided right before an exam, and if it is possible to practice with an answer key to check our understanding throughout the semester that would be great).
It was a fun course however some of the topics were slightly difficult
The class instruction felt very estranged from the homework and exams.
cj was a very good teacher, it could be improved by making office hours more accessible and by getting rid of explorations
I thought it felt a little disorganized at times, and like the pace at which we covered topics was inconsistent

One strength is the course director, Rachel Diethorn, who gave tons of information and was an incredibly positive and helpful course director. One main weakness was the individual section teachers  Although I see the argument for grad students teaching because it allows for smaller sections, I would have preferred one big lecture with a better teacher. It would be great to maybe have an option between a bigger lecture and smaller seminar classes (like how the economics department sets up their intro level classes). I though another big weakness was the amount of true and false on the exams. Though I understand that true and false questions are easier to grade, I thought they accounted for way to much of the final exam (one exam had 4 questions each worth 5/100 points), especially since they dont take any partial credit.
Strengths: small class sections, taught at a fast pace

This course has a significant amount of assignments. Psets every week, yet they only count for 10% of the total grade. Majority of your grade hinges on exam performance. Your level of engagement with your course is impacted by the strength of your instructor. From my experience, I ended up going to other sections taught by Rachel Diethorn as her teaching style was significantly more beneficial to my learning compared to my assigned instructor. If you have a choice in section preference, choose professor Diethorn.
I wish that we did more questions like the ones on our problem-sets in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course to another student. If you need a QR credit, there are much easier ones out there. Most of the people who take this class do so to full major requirements (which is a lot of people), so I would only recommend it if you have to.
Yes, this class was challenging but doable especially with office hours and peer tutors.
Yes because I think it provides foundational knowledge
I would recommend this course to another student if they wish to continue their journey in mathematics and if it is necessary for their major.
Yes, this is a very good course for learning the fundamentals of Calculus II. The workload is not too overwhelming while still being helpful for understanding the material.
I believe this course provided a good foundation for Calculus 2, and it would be helpful regardless of whether or not you have previously learned the material.
I would recommend this course to anyone who must take calculus.

I would recommend this course to another student. It is well taught and there is ample support for students. For students who prefer classes that weigh teams heavily for the final grade, this course is particularly good since the final exam can count as 55% of your grade.
Yes if they are interested in Math, Calc BC is an important course for further math concepts
yes - i feel like i learned a lot
Yes. Its definitely beneficial for learning these topics.
Probably not. It is a prerequisite, which I assume is why most people enroll in this class. Unless you enjoy Calc II, don't take this course.
I would recommend this course to another student, adding that office hours are very important.
